[and yes, if you're tampering with the wireless regulatory domain then you're very likely doing something you should not be doing]
i can not think of a legitimate reason to bypass/modify the kernel's wireless regulatory domain database
but there's an increasing focus on configurable radios and ensuring they are locked down away from the user through cryptographic means
there are aftermarket firmwares for those machines that allow you to bypass that check
but now you're patching your machine's UEFI with some non-vetted product which you may not have the ability to check yourself
so security risk beware
the firmware update pulled an Intel and disabled creating an access point in the 5 GHz band

Think of the kernel as a layered architecture. You have your subsystems (I2C, SPI, PCIe...). For the subsystems to interact with the hardware, you need drivers for your hardware. You need to make your drivers and register them with that subsystem. Now, you have drivers that make use of a particular subsystem. For example, say that you're dealing with an SGP30 sensor. That is an air quality/chemical sensor. It uses I2C to communicate with your platform.

In Linux, the driver for that is in the IIO subsystem. It registers itself in the IIO subsystem of the kernel, and it calls upon functions from the I2C subsystem to perform reads/writes to the sensor.
The I2C subsystem then talks to your I2C controller driver (a platform driver) to actually access the hardware.

you can go multiple ways:
- add an overlay at boot time to add the proper node(s) so that your device can be detected
- obtain the original device tree, modify it by adding the additional node(s) for your device
- decompile the current devie tree, and modify it by adding the additional node(s)
for that you need to consult the documentation for the device tree bindings for whatever kernel module you need to use for your device
as long as the chip supports it, linux should be able to hook up interrupts sufficiently

i have had to do this on a number of linuxy embedded platforms, but have done only the tiniest hacking on android
the device tree does not provide the hardware support
the kernel modules provide the hardware support
if you add that to the device tree, you're telling the kernel to never shut off that regulator
when dealing with a GPIO regulator, the kernel will reserve the pin on the GPIO port you specified for regulator usage

In some cases, it would read 0x19C5 instead of 0x1985.

So, I think it could be the SPI timing.

Just for reference, in the old working kernel version, the max frequency was set to 133 MHz. And this lines up with what's stated in their [datasheet](https://www.mxic.com.tw/Lists/Datasheet/Attachments/8959/MX66L2G45G,%203V,%202Gb,%20v1.1.pdf), particularly Page 28.
